questions.question_text:
A development team wants to use AWS CloudFormation stacks to deploy an application. However, the developer IAM role does not have the required permissions to provision the resources that are specified in the AWS CloudFormation template. A DevOps engineer needs to implement a solution that allows the developers to deploy the stacks. The solution must follow the principle of least privilege.

Which solution will meet these requirements?

choices.A: Create an IAM policy that allows the developers to provision the required resources. Attach the policy to the developer IAM role.
choices.B: Create an IAM policy that allows full access to AWS CloudFormation. Attach the policy to the developer IAM role.
choices.D: Create an AWS CloudFormation service role that has the required permissions. Grant the developer IAM role the iam:PassRole permission. Use the new service role during stack deployments.
choices.C: Create an AWS CloudFormation service role that has the required permissions. Grant the developer IAM role a cloudforrnation:* action. Use the new service role during stack deployments.

discussion.content: D-D-D-D-D-D-D-

Selected Answer: D
A, does not follow the least privilege principle because the developers will have access to provision the resources without using CloudFormation.
B, full access gives too much accesses.
C, cloudformation:*.action gives too much accesses.

Selected Answer: D
D is correct. As an IAM user you need to have the IAM policy that allow you to pass the service role you are assigning to CloudFormation to execute the template to create/ update stack.

D is the correct option
